topics.title: Adam Smith: The Invisible Hand

hook.text: A Scottish professor wrote a book in 1776 that became the Bible of capitalism. He never used the word 'capitalism.'

buildup.text: Adam Smith's 'Wealth of Nations' argued that self-interest, not charity, drives economic prosperity for everyone.

discovery.text: The invisible hand: when a baker bakes for profit, the town gets bread.

twist.text: Smith also warned that businessmen conspire to fix prices and exploit workers.

climax.text: Smith's insight: markets coordinate millions of decisions without a central plan. No person designs it. It just works.

punchline.text: Capitalism's founder was also its first critic.

quiz.question: What is Adam Smith's 'invisible hand' concept?
options: Individual self-interest unintentionally creating broader social benefit through market forces

topics.title: David Ricardo: Comparative Advantage Explained

hook.text: Even if you're better at everything than your neighbor, you should still specialize. David Ricardo proved why in 1817.

buildup.text: Ricardo used England (cloth) and Portugal (wine) as examples.

discovery.text: Comparative advantage: specialize in what you do relatively best and trade for the rest.

twist.text: Ricardo was a self-made stock trader worth $100 million (today's value) who bought a seat in Parliament to push free.

climax.text: Comparative advantage is the foundation of all international trade.

punchline.text: Even the best at everything benefits from not doing everything.

quiz.question: What does comparative advantage mean?
options: The country with the most resources wins
Nations benefit by specializing in what they produce relatively most efficiently and trading
Only rich countries benefit from trade

topics.title: Thomas Malthus: The Population Bomb

hook.text: In 1798, Malthus predicted humanity was doomed. Population grows exponentially; food grows linearly.

buildup.text: His math seemed irrefutable: population doubles every 25 years, but farmland doesn't.

discovery.text: The 'Malthusian trap' did describe all of human history until 1800. For millennia, more people just meant more poverty.

twist.text: Then industrialization shattered his prediction. Technology increased food production faster than population growth.

climax.text: Malthus gave economics its nickname: 'the dismal science.' He was wrong about the future but right about the past.

punchline.text: The most famous prediction in economics was spectacularly wrong.

quiz.question: Why was Malthus's prediction ultimately wrong?
options: Technological innovation increased food production faster than population growth

topics.title: Karl Marx: The Economist Who Changed History

hook.text: A broke journalist sitting in the British Library wrote a book that inspired revolutions on every continent.

buildup.text: Marx argued that capitalism exploits workers: they create value but owners keep the profit.

discovery.text: Marx predicted capitalism would concentrate wealth until workers revolted.

twist.text: Every communist revolution happened in poor, agricultural countries â€” the opposite of what Marx predicted.

climax.text: Marx was wrong about the revolution but arguably right about concentration.

punchline.text: Marx's worst predictions shaped the 20th century more than anyone's best ones.

quiz.question: What did Marx predict would happen to capitalism?
options: Wealth concentration would grow until workers revolted and overthrew the system

topics.title: John Stuart Mill: Freedom Meets Economics

hook.text: A child prodigy who read Greek at age three grew up to argue that economics must serve human freedom.

buildup.text: Mill separated production from distribution.

discovery.text: He was the first major economist to advocate for women's rights, workers' cooperatives, and progressive taxation.

twist.text: Mill predicted a 'stationary state' where growth stops but quality of life improves.

climax.text: Mill bridged capitalism and social justice.

punchline.text: The first economist to say growth isn't everything was right all along.

quiz.question: What was Mill's key distinction in economics?
options: Production follows market laws, but distribution of wealth is a social choice

topics.title: Alfred Marshall: Supply, Demand, and the Scissors

hook.text: Before 1890, economists fought: does value come from production cost or buyer desire? Marshall said both.

buildup.text: Marshall drew the supply and demand diagram every economics student learns.

discovery.text: His 'Principles of Economics' textbook dominated for 50 years.

twist.text: Marshall deliberately wrote in plain English and hid the math in footnotes.

climax.text: Every price you pay is the result of Marshall's scissors â€” supply meeting demand at one precise point.

punchline.text: The most important chart in economics fits on a napkin.

quiz.question: What was Alfred Marshall's 'scissors' analogy about?
options: Both supply and demand determine price, like both blades of scissors cut

topics.title: LÃ©on Walras: The Dream of General Equilibrium

hook.text: What if every market â€” apples, labor, steel, haircuts.

buildup.text: Walras's general equilibrium theory showed that all markets are interconnected.

discovery.text: He proved mathematically that under ideal conditions, all markets can reach equilibrium simultaneously.

twist.text: His theory requires perfect competition, perfect information, and no transaction costs.

climax.text: Walras built the mathematical skeleton of modern economics â€” beautiful, rigorous, and almost impossible to apply.

punchline.text: Economics' most elegant theory describes a world that doesn't exist.

quiz.question: What did Walras's general equilibrium theory demonstrate?
options: Under ideal conditions, all interconnected markets can reach simultaneous balance

topics.title: Thorstein Veblen: The Theory of the Leisure Class

hook.text: In 1899, an eccentric Norwegian-American professor explained why rich people buy useless expensive things.

buildup.text: Veblen argued the wealthy don't just buy utility â€” they buy status.

discovery.text: He identified 'Veblen goods' â€” products that sell more at higher prices because the high price IS the value.

twist.text: Veblen was fired from multiple universities for sleeping with faculty wives.

climax.text: Veblen showed that consumption is social, not rational. We buy things to communicate who we are, not just what we need.

punchline.text: We buy expensive things to show we can afford to waste money.

quiz.question: What is conspicuous consumption according to Veblen?
options: Purchasing expensive goods primarily to display wealth and social status

topics.title: Irving Fisher: The Debt Deflation Theory

hook.text: In 1929, Irving Fisher declared 'stocks have reached a permanently high plateau.' Weeks later, the market crashed 89%.

buildup.text: Fisher lost his fortune and his reputation.

discovery.text: Debt deflation: when prices fall, debts become heavier in real terms.

twist.text: Fisher's theory was ignored for 70 years. Then 2008 happened â€” exactly the debt deflation spiral he described.

climax.text: The economist who made the worst prediction in history also made one of the most important discoveries about financial.

punchline.text: The man who missed the crash explained how crashes work.

quiz.question: What is Fisher's debt deflation theory?
options: Falling prices increase real debt burdens, causing forced selling that pushes prices down further

topics.title: Joseph Schumpeter: Creative Destruction

hook.text: Schumpeter said capitalism's greatest feature is that it destroys itself â€” and that's what makes it work.

buildup.text: Creative destruction: new innovations destroy old industries. Cars killed horse carriages.

discovery.text: The entrepreneur is capitalism's hero â€” not the manager.

twist.text: Schumpeter predicted capitalism would be destroyed by its own success.

climax.text: Every industry disruption today â€” Uber, Airbnb, AI â€” is Schumpeter's creative destruction playing out in real time.

punchline.text: Capitalism progresses not by perfecting the old but by destroying it.

quiz.question: What is Schumpeter's concept of creative destruction?
options: Innovation constantly disrupts and replaces existing industries, driving economic progress

topics.title: John Maynard Keynes: The Man Who Saved Capitalism

hook.text: During the Great Depression, economists said 'wait â€” markets will fix themselves.

buildup.text: Classical economics assumed unemployed workers would accept lower wages until everyone had jobs.

discovery.text: Keynes argued that during recessions, government must spend to replace missing private demand.

twist.text: Keynes was also a wildly successful investor. He turned his college's endowment into a fortune by buying during panics.

climax.text: Keynesian economics â€” government intervention during downturns.

punchline.text: The man who saved capitalism did it by telling governments to spend.

quiz.question: What was Keynes's revolutionary idea during the Great Depression?
options: Cut government spending to balance budgets
Government should increase spending during recessions to replace missing private demand

topics.title: The Paradox of Thrift: When Saving Kills the Economy

hook.text: Saving money is smart for you. But if everyone saves at once, the economy collapses.

buildup.text: When people fear recession, they cut spending and save more. But one person's spending is another's income.

discovery.text: If everyone saves simultaneously, total demand drops, businesses close, jobs disappear, and incomes fall.

twist.text: Japan experienced exactly this for 30 years. High savings, low spending, deflation, stagnation.

climax.text: The paradox of thrift shows that what's rational for one person can be catastrophic when everyone does it.

punchline.text: When everyone saves for a rainy day, it starts raining.

quiz.question: What is the paradox of thrift?
options: When everyone saves simultaneously, reduced spending causes economic decline that lowers total savings

topics.title: Animal Spirits: Why Economies Run on Emotion

hook.text: Keynes said business investment isn't driven by spreadsheets.

buildup.text: No one can calculate the return on a 20-year factory. The numbers are guesses.

discovery.text: When confidence collapses, investment freezes â€” even if interest rates are zero.

twist.text: George Akerlof and Robert Shiller revived animal spirits in 2009.

climax.text: Economies aren't machines â€” they're ecosystems of human emotion. Confidence is the fuel, and fear is the brake.

punchline.text: The economy runs on feelings more than facts.

quiz.question: What are Keynes's 'animal spirits'?
options: The emotional confidence and gut feelings that drive business investment decisions

topics.title: The Liquidity Trap: When Interest Rates Hit Zero

hook.text: Japan cut interest rates to zero in 1999. The economy didn't recover.

buildup.text: Normally, lower interest rates encourage borrowing and spending. But at zero, you can't go lower.

discovery.text: Keynes predicted this: the liquidity trap. When rates are zero, people hoard cash instead of investing.

twist.text: Paul Krugman warned in 1998 that liquidity traps were real. Mainstream economists laughed.

climax.text: The liquidity trap shows monetary policy has limits.

punchline.text: You can lead an economy to cheap money, but you can't make it borrow.

quiz.question: What is a liquidity trap?
options: Interest rates at zero fail to stimulate borrowing because people prefer holding cash
Government debt too high to borrow

topics.title: Hyman Minsky: Stability Creates Instability

hook.text: Minsky's idea was ignored for decades, then 2008 hit. Now 'Minsky moment' is a phrase every financial journalist uses.

buildup.text: Minsky argued that long periods of economic stability make people complacent.

discovery.text: He identified three stages: hedge finance (safe), speculative finance (risky).

twist.text: The 2008 housing crisis followed Minsky's script exactly: safe lending â†’ risky lending â†’ Ponzi lending â†’ collapse.

climax.text: Minsky proved that financial crises aren't accidents.

punchline.text: The calmest markets are the most dangerous ones.

quiz.question: What is a 'Minsky moment'?
options: The point where excessive speculation and debt accumulated during stability causes a sudden market crash

topics.title: Friedrich Hayek: The Knowledge Problem

hook.text: Can a central planner set the price of bread, steel, and a million other goods correctly? Hayek said no.

buildup.text: Hayek argued that economic knowledge is dispersed among millions of people.

discovery.text: Prices are information signals. When steel gets scarce, its price rises â€” telling everyone to use less and produce more.

twist.text: Central planning fails not because planners are stupid.

climax.text: Hayek showed that markets are information processors.

punchline.text: No government is smart enough to set a million prices correctly.

quiz.question: What is Hayek's 'knowledge problem'?
options: Economic knowledge is dispersed among millions â€” no central planner can collect and use it all

topics.title: Milton Friedman: Money Rules Everything

hook.text: Friedman argued the Great Depression wasn't caused by capitalism failing.

buildup.text: His monetarist theory: inflation is always and everywhere a monetary phenomenon.

discovery.text: Friedman's research showed that Fed policy errors â€” too tight in 1929, too loose in the 1970s.

twist.text: Friedman advised Pinochet's Chile. His economic ideas worked.

climax.text: Today's central banks target inflation, not employment.

punchline.text: The man who said government was the problem changed how every government.

quiz.question: What was Friedman's explanation of the Great Depression?
options: The Federal Reserve made it worse by wrongly shrinking the money supply

topics.title: Gary Becker: Economics of Everything

hook.text: Becker used economics to analyze crime, marriage, drug addiction, and discrimination. Economists were horrified.

buildup.text: His insight: rational choice theory applies everywhere. Criminals weigh costs vs. benefits.

discovery.text: Becker's economics of discrimination showed that prejudice is costly.

twist.text: His 'rotten kid theorem' proves even a selfish child will act generously if the family head redistributes income.

climax.text: Becker expanded economics from a study of markets to a study of all human behavior.

punchline.text: Economics isn't about money. It's about how humans make decisions.

quiz.question: How did Becker expand the scope of economics?
options: He focused only on financial markets
He applied rational choice analysis to non-market behavior like crime, marriage, and discrimination

topics.title: James Buchanan: Public Choice Theory

hook.text: Why do governments waste money? Buchanan's answer: because politicians are self-interested, just like everyone else.

buildup.text: Traditional economics assumed government actors are benevolent.

discovery.text: Public choice theory: politicians maximize votes, bureaucrats maximize budgets.

twist.text: A $10 million subsidy benefits one company intensely. It costs each taxpayer 3 cents.

climax.text: Buchanan showed that 'government failure' is as real as market failure.

punchline.text: Governments fail for the same reason markets do.

quiz.question: What is the core insight of public choice theory?
options: Government actors are self-interested like everyone else â€” they maximize votes and budgets, not public welfare

topics.title: Ronald Coase: The Cost of Transactions

hook.text: Why do firms exist? If markets are efficient, everyone should be a freelancer. Coase answered this in 1937 â€” at age 27.

buildup.text: Coase argued that using markets has costs: finding sellers, negotiating contracts, enforcing deals.

discovery.text: Firms exist to reduce transaction costs.

twist.text: Coase's theorem also says if property rights are clear and bargaining is free.

climax.text: Coase won the Nobel at 80 years old. Two papers, no math, pure logic â€” among the most cited in all of economics.

punchline.text: Companies exist because talking to strangers is expensive.

quiz.question: According to Coase, why do firms exist?
options: Firms reduce transaction costs that would make market-based coordination too expensive

topics.title: Amartya Sen: Economics as Freedom

hook.text: As a child in Bengal, Sen watched three million people die in a famine.

buildup.text: Sen proved famines aren't caused by food shortages.

discovery.text: His capability approach: development isn't about GDP growth.

twist.text: No democracy with a free press has ever experienced a famine.

climax.text: Sen redefined development economics: freedom isn't the result of development. Freedom IS development.

punchline.text: Prosperity without freedom is a prison with better meals.

quiz.question: What did Sen discover about the causes of famines?
options: Failures of distribution, rights, and political accountability â€” not food shortages

topics.title: Daniel Kahneman: The Psychologist Who Won the Economics Nobel

hook.text: Kahneman never took an economics class. He won the Nobel Prize in Economics in 2002. His field was psychology.

buildup.text: With Amos Tversky, Kahneman showed that humans systematically deviate from rational decision-making in predictable ways.

discovery.text: System 1 (fast, intuitive) and System 2 (slow, deliberate): most economic decisions are made by the fast system.

twist.text: Tversky died in 1996, six years before the Nobel. The prize cannot be awarded posthumously. Their work was inseparable.

climax.text: Kahneman proved that 'homo economicus' â€” the rational agent of economic theory â€” doesn't exist.

punchline.text: The most important economist of our era was never an economist.

quiz.question: What did Kahneman's research prove about economic behavior?
options: Humans systematically deviate from rationality in predictable, bias-driven ways

topics.title: Elinor Ostrom: Governing the Commons

hook.text: Economists said shared resources like fisheries and forests must be privatized or they'll be destroyed.

buildup.text: The 'tragedy of the commons' argument: individuals overuse shared resources because no one owns them.

discovery.text: Ostrom studied communities worldwide that successfully managed commons for centuries.

twist.text: She was the first (and still only) woman to win the Nobel in Economics.

climax.text: Ostrom showed a third way: communities can self-govern shared resources through trust, rules, and local knowledge.

punchline.text: The best solution to shared resource problems was hiding in fishing villages.

quiz.question: What did Ostrom discover about managing shared resources?
options: Communities can successfully self-govern common resources without privatization or state control

topics.title: Thomas Piketty: Capital in the Twenty-First Century

hook.text: A French economist wrote a 700-page book about inequality. It sold 2.5 million copies and terrified billionaires.

buildup.text: Piketty gathered 200 years of tax data from 20+ countries.

discovery.text: Without intervention, wealth concentrates naturally.

twist.text: Critics attacked his data, his methodology, and his conclusions.

climax.text: Piketty showed that extreme inequality isn't a bug in capitalism.

punchline.text: r > g: two letters that explain why the rich keep getting richer.

quiz.question: What does Piketty's formula 'r > g' mean?
options: When returns on capital exceed economic growth, inequality naturally increases
Rich countries grow faster than poor ones

topics.title: Daron Acemoglu: Why Nations Fail

hook.text: Why is Nogales, Arizona rich while Nogales, Mexico (across the fence) is poor? Same geography, same people.

buildup.text: Acemoglu and Robinson argued that inclusive institutions â€” property rights, rule of law, political participation.

discovery.text: Extractive institutions â€” where elites capture resources.

twist.text: They used colonial history as a natural experiment: colonies where Europeans settled got good institutions.

climax.text: Development isn't about aid or geography.

punchline.text: Rich countries aren't lucky. They have better rules.

quiz.question: According to Acemoglu, what primarily determines whether nations prosper or fail?
options: Whether their institutions are inclusive (serving all) or extractive (serving elites)

topics.title: Esther Duflo: The Randomistas

hook.text: At 46, Duflo became the youngest person and second woman to win the Economics Nobel. Her weapon: randomized experiments.

buildup.text: Development economics relied on grand theories. Duflo said: stop guessing, start testing.

discovery.text: Duflo's experiments revealed surprises: bed nets save more lives than hospitals.

twist.text: Critics say her experiments are too small to change policy.

climax.text: Duflo proved that fighting poverty isn't about ideology â€” left or right. It's about evidence: what actually works?

punchline.text: The best way to fight poverty is to test what works, not to guess.

quiz.question: What methodological innovation did Esther Duflo bring to development economics?
options: Randomized controlled experiments to test what actually reduces poverty

topics.title: Claudia Goldin: The Gender Pay Gap Decoded

hook.text: In 2023, Claudia Goldin became the third woman ever to win the Economics Nobel. Her subject: 200 years of women's work.

buildup.text: Goldin traced women's labor force participation from 1800 to today. It's not a simple upward line â€” it's U-shaped.

discovery.text: The gender pay gap isn't mainly about discrimination.

twist.text: The gap explodes after the first child. Mothers shift to flexible jobs; fathers don't.

climax.text: Goldin showed that closing the pay gap requires redesigning jobs, not just fighting bias.

punchline.text: The pay gap isn't a glass ceiling. It's a greedy clock.

quiz.question: According to Goldin, what primarily drives the modern gender pay gap?
options: Jobs that disproportionately reward long, inflexible hours â€” penalizing those with caregiving duties

topics.title: The Future of Economics: What Comes Next?

hook.text: Economics failed to predict 2008. Climate change defies its models. AI is transforming labor.

buildup.text: New economics integrates psychology, ecology, network science, and computation.

discovery.text: Kate Raworth's 'Doughnut Economics' proposes a new goal: meet human needs without overshooting planetary boundaries.

twist.text: AI can now process economic data that no human team could analyze.

climax.text: The next great economist might not be a person at all.

punchline.text: Economics keeps evolving because the economy never stops changing.

quiz.question: How is economics evolving in the 21st century?
options: Integrating psychology, ecology, AI, and network science to move beyond rational-agent models

topics.title: Robert Shiller: Markets Are Narratives

hook.text: Robert Shiller warned of the dot-com bubble in 2000 and the housing bubble in 2005. Both times, almost nobody listened.

buildup.text: Shiller showed that stock prices swing far more than company earnings justify. Markets are driven by emotion, not math.

discovery.text: His concept of 'narrative economics' argues that viral stories â€” not data â€” drive booms and busts in markets.

twist.text: His Case-Shiller Index tracks home prices and became the metric that measured the 2008 crash he predicted.

climax.text: Shiller proved that markets are human institutions, not computing machines. Stories move money more than spreadsheets.

punchline.text: Markets don't follow data. They follow the stories we tell about data.

quiz.question: What is Shiller's concept of 'narrative economics'?
options: Viral stories drive economic booms and busts

topics.title: The Replication Crisis: When Economic Studies Fail

hook.text: A team tried to replicate 18 famous economics experiments. Only 11 produced the same results.

buildup.text: Economics relies on studies to guide policy.

discovery.text: Publication bias is a culprit: journals publish surprising results and reject boring confirmations.

twist.text: Some debunked results still appear in textbooks. Ideas that entered policy decades ago were never checked again.

climax.text: The crisis is forcing economics to adopt pre-registration, open data, and replication studies.

punchline.text: Good science doubts itself. Great science proves itself wrong.

quiz.question: What did replication studies reveal about economics research?
options: About a third of famous results couldn't be reproduced
